docs.lead_paragraph: Brother Rémy Rougeau could smell the nectar. Even now, in the hush of an abbey cloister, with the prairie road too muddy to reach the hives. He could imagine the sweet boozy scent of honeybees quickening like roiling clouds. Summer is a season of timeless ritual for Brother Rougeau, a beekeeper and Benedictine monk. He must check the queens, tend the colonies and prepare for a late harvest of sweet clover honey that tastes of the Great Plains. And he must doff his black habit for a book tour in the Northeast to promote his first novel, ''All We Know of Heaven.''

headline.main: A Life With God, Articulated; A Monk Swimming in the Stream of Books and Bees

docs.abstract: Interview with Brother Remy Rougeau, Benedictine monk and author of new novel All We Know of Heaven; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Back from his European tour, President Bush this week faces what could be a bruising political battle against his old nemesis John McCain and a united Democratic front as the Senate begins to debate a patients' bill of rights. So far, the president is on the wrong side of this fight, both on the merits and as a political matter. He ought to reconsider his opposition to empowering people to seek meaningful redress from their health care plans when they are wrongly denied medical coverage. A patients' bill of rights is long overdue. Millions of Americans have little or no recourse to contest wrongful denials of medical coverage, or to seek damages arising from such denials. It is far more difficult under current law to sue managed-care organizations than it is to sue doctors. But with health plans and insurance companies making more and more medical care decisions, it is important that they be held as accountable as doctors are held for their actions. Individuals should be able to challenge them before an independent arbitrator or in court.

headline.main: The Right Patients' Bill of Rights

docs.lead_paragraph: Like almost every other deadline in Albany, the end of the legislative session on Wednesday is something of a fiction. Unless unexpected political shifts occur, lawmakers will go home without passing a budget, now 11 weeks late, or reaching agreement on most major bills before them. They know they will have to return to the capital sometime later this year to pass a spending plan. And if the past serves as any guide, the most important bills will either be rolled into the budget or will become bargaining chips in the budget talks between the governor and legislative leaders. The real end of the session comes when the budget is passed.

headline.main: In Albany, It's Not Begun Till It's Over

docs.abstract: Article reviews legislation that has been passed in Albany--and unfinished legislation that has been mired in negotiation and squabbling--during past legislative session; senators will leave shortly but will have to return at some point to pass budget bill; assembly will stay and try to work out agreements with Gov Pataki; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: EVER wonder what our lawmakers do while waiting around for Albany's leaders to make a deal on the budget? It is 11 weeks late, with no resolution in sight. Wonder no more. A favorite pastime in the state capital is busywork, introducing bills that are destined to fail, but intended to appeal to discrete constituencies and special interests.

headline.main: Metro Matters; Even if It Fails, This Bill May Succeed

docs.abstract: Joyce Purnick Metro Matters column discusses practice of introducing legislation that is doomed to fail in order to appeal to specific constituences; cites introduction of bill that would criminalize killing of fetus, passage of which would undermine abortion law; bill will not pass, but its introduction will satisfy conservative voting bloc (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate opens debate this week on the regulation of health maintenance organizations, putting protections for more than 170 million Americans with private health insurance at the center of the first test of strength between President Bush and the newly ascendant Senate Democrats. Lobbyists and lawmakers alike will be watching the Senate closely for insights into how Washington will work under the new political alignment: Who will control the policy agenda? Will compromise or confrontation become the norm? And can the issue that has been fought over in dozens of campaigns finally make it into law?

headline.main: SENATE CONSIDERS PATIENTS' RIGHTS IN TEST WITH BUSH

docs.abstract: Senate will begin debate within week on regulation of health maintenance organizations; will focus on protections for more than 170 million Americans with private health insurance in first test of strength between newly ascendant Senate Democrats and Pres Bush; Democrats, who lost Control of Congress in 1994 on heels of failure to enact Pres Clinton's ambitious plan for universal national health insurance, will try to define wide range of new rights for those who have insurance--including broad new guarantees that patients can seek redress in court; major sticking point with Bush administration is what rights patients should have to sue HMO's and in which courts; Bush says he opposes bill favored by Democrats and has threatened veto; majority leader Sen Tom Daschle says Democrats have compromised as much as they possibly can; provisions of competing bills sponsored by Sens John McCain, John Edwards, Ted Kennedy and Sen Bill Frist, John Breaux and Jim Jeffords compared; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Daniel Altman, an economics correspondent for The Economist magazine, is joining the editorial board of The New York Times today. His appointment as an editorial writer was announced by Howell Raines, editorial page editor. Mr. Altman, 26, who was based in London, has reported on international trade and other economic issues worldwide for The Economist since June 2000. He also wrote occasional ''leaders'' expressing the editorial opinion of the magazine, as well as columns on economic thinking, under the title Economic Focus.

docs.lead_paragraph: ANY minute now, the men and women of Congress will hunker down to discuss prescription-drug benefits under Medicare, and the rights that Americans should have if they are enrolled in H.M.O.'s. In the meantime, however, a more complicated insurance problem is brewing, with serious public health implications, and few lawmakers have been willing to take it up: Who should pay for the health insurance of immigrants?

headline.main: Patients Without a Country: Who Pays?

docs.lead_paragraph: SUDDENLY, fleetingly, in Fairfield County, a theater fanatic's crazy dream has leaped into real time. Two esoteric plays, each charting another age, another world, are happening in professional productions on two separate stages here. One, ''Princess Turandot,'' has grandly opened the season in a perennial playhouse rooted in legend. The other, ''Diana of Dobson's,'' is a long shot by a start-up company in a makeshift space.

headline.main: Seeing Another Age On Separate Stages

docs.abstract: Article on summer showcase productions of Princess Turandot by Blue Light Theater Company in Westport, Conn, and Diana of Dobson at Fairfield University's Wien Experimental Theater; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the American Stage Company in Teaneck, spiraling into debt, canceled the second half of its season in March, arts executives across New Jersey double-checked their books and counted their blessings. ''It's like, 'There but for the grace of God . . . ,' '' said Laura Ekstrand, the artistic director of the Dreamcatcher Repertory Theater in Bloomfield. ''When something like that happens, it rattles people.''
docs.abstract: Article on likelihood that New Jersey legislature, facing revenue shortfall of about $1 billion, may not approve $5 million increase in funding to New Jersey State Council on the Arts; figures show that demand for state support is highest ever, with more than 200 arts groups seeking $32.7 million; arts executives describe competition for share of funding as brutal and draining; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a victory for women's-rights groups -- and all working women who spend hundreds of their own dollars a year on birth-control pills -- a Federal judge in Seattle ruled that Bartell Drug Co. engaged in sex discrimination by offering health insurance that covered male employees' basic health needs, but excluded the prescription contraceptives that women use. The judge said that under the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, ''the law is no longer blind to the fact that only women can get pregnant, bear children or use prescription contraception.'' Tamar Lewin
